verses.text: Now the leaders of the people lived in Jerusalem, but the rest of the people cast lots to bring one out of every ten to live in Jerusalem, the holy city, while the remaining nine would stay in the other towns.
verses.comment: Casting lots was a common biblical way to discern God's will (cf. Acts 1:26). The emphasis on Jerusalem as the 'holy city' foreshadows its significance as a central place of worship.

verses.text: And the people blessed all the men who willingly offered to live in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Dwelling in Jerusalem involved sacrifice and devotion, pointing toward the self-giving nature of true worship and obedience.

verses.text: These are the chiefs of the province who lived in Jerusalem, but in the towns of Judah, every man lived on his property in their towns—Israel, the priests, the Levites, the temple servants, and the descendants of Solomon’s servants.
verses.comment: The organization of the people reflects the covenant community's structure—priesthood, Levites, and servants, highlighting the importance of order and continuity in worship.

verses.text: In Jerusalem lived some of the sons of Judah and of Benjamin. Of the sons of Judah: Athaiah the son of Uzziah, son of Zechariah, son of Amariah, son of Shephatiah, son of Mahalalel, of the sons of Perez;
verses.comment: Perez's line is highlighted, showing continuity with the ancestry of David, and ultimately with the Messiah.

verses.text: And Maaseiah the son of Baruch, son of Col-hozeh, son of Hazaiah, son of Adaiah, son of Joiarib, son of Zechariah, son of the Shilonite.
verses.comment: Lineages are carefully kept to ensure faithfulness to God's promises and to identify rightful leaders.

verses.text: All the sons of Perez who lived in Jerusalem were 468 valiant men.
verses.comment: The mention of 'valiant men' marks the importance of spiritual and physical strength among the faithful, both for defense and worship.

verses.text: And these are the sons of Benjamin: Sallu the son of Meshullam, son of Joed, son of Pedaiah, son of Kolaiah, son of Maaseiah, son of Ithiel, son of Jeshaiah,
verses.comment: The listing of Benjamin’s descendants points toward the faithful remnant among God’s people.

verses.text: and his brothers, men of valor, 928.
verses.comment: Men of valor are called out, not only for their military ability but as servants devoted to the common good of the city.

verses.text: Joel the son of Zichri was their overseer, and Judah the son of Hassenuah was second over the city.
verses.comment: Leadership among the tribes ensured proper governance, echoing the need for order and unity in God’s people.

verses.text: Of the priests: Jedaiah the son of Joiarib, Jachin,
verses.comment: Priestly families resided in Jerusalem for the worship at the reconstructed temple.

verses.text: Seraiah the son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub, ruler of the house of God,
verses.comment: ‘Ruler of the house of God’ signifies his high priestly role, a type foreshadowing Christ our High Priest (Heb. 4:14).

verses.text: and their brothers who did the work of the house, 822. And Adaiah the son of Jeroham, son of Pelaliah, son of Amzi, son of Zechariah, son of Pashhur, son of Malchijah,
verses.comment: Those who ‘did the work of the house’ draw a picture of a worshiping community, emphasizing the communal nature of serving God.

verses.text: and his brothers, heads of fathers’ houses, 242; and Amashsai the son of Azarel, son of Ahzai, son of Meshillemoth, son of Immer,
verses.comment: Houses (or families) were the structure through which faith was preserved and passed along generations—a reminder of household faithfulness.

verses.text: and their brothers, mighty men of valor, 128. Their overseer was Zabdiel the son of Haggedolim.
verses.comment: ‘Mighty men of valor’ recalls Old Testament heroes; Zabdiel’s leadership shows the necessity of strong spiritual and civic leaders.

verses.text: Of the Levites: Shemaiah the son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, son of Bunni;
verses.comment: Levites were tasked with assisting in temple worship and instruction—a model for ministerial service in the Church today.

verses.text: and Shabbethai and Jozabad, of the chiefs of the Levites, who were over the outside work of the house of God.
verses.comment: Some Levites had administrative, not liturgical, duties—showing a division of labor for the good order of worship.

verses.text: And Mattaniah the son of Mica, son of Zabdi, son of Asaph, who was the leader in beginning the thanksgiving in prayer; and Bakbukiah, the second among his brothers; and Abda the son of Shammua, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun.
verses.comment: Asaph and Jeduthun’s descendants leading in worship emphasizes sung prayer and thanksgiving—a hint at the liturgical tradition of God’s people.

verses.text: All the Levites in the holy city were 284.
verses.comment: A substantial number of Levites attended to the spiritual life of Jerusalem, underlining the city’s religious centrality.

verses.text: And the gatekeepers, Akkub, Talmon and their brothers, who kept watch at the gates, were 172.
verses.comment: Gatekeepers not only provided security but symbolic purity—only the clean could approach God’s sanctuary.

verses.text: The rest of Israel, and of the priests and Levites, were in all the towns of Judah, every one in his inheritance.
verses.comment: The people lived throughout Judah, reminding us of God’s promise to give each tribe their inheritance; the idea of spiritual inheritance remains central in Christian hope (cf. 1 Pet. 1:4).

verses.text: But the temple servants lived on Ophel; and Ziha and Gishpa were over them.
verses.comment: ‘Ophel’ refers to a fortified part of Jerusalem, near the temple. Temple servants filled supporting roles, paralleling the many necessary ministries in every age of the Church.

verses.text: The overseer of the Levites in Jerusalem was Uzzi the son of Bani, son of Hashabiah, son of Mattaniah, son of Mica, of the sons of Asaph, the singers, in charge of the work of the house of God.
verses.comment: The tradition of worship through music was handed down in Asaph’s lineage, signifying the centrality of beauty and order in worship.

verses.text: For there was a command from the king concerning them, and a fixed provision for the singers, as each day required.
verses.comment: Daily provision for worshipers recalls God’s constant care and the need for daily prayer and praise (cf. Ps. 55:17; Dan. 6:10).

verses.text: And Pethahiah the son of Meshezabel, of the sons of Zerah the son of Judah, was at the king's side for all matters concerning the people.
verses.comment: This role is like an advocate or mediator—foreshadowing Christ’s mediation (1 Tim. 2:5) and the necessity of intercessors before God.

verses.text: As for the villages, with their fields, some of the people of Judah lived in Kiriath-arba and its villages, Dibon and its villages, and in Jekabzeel and its villages,
verses.comment: These territorial notes establish the faithfulness of Israel to their inheritance and their dwelling in holiness on the land God gave them.

verses.text: and in Jeshua and in Moladah and Beth-pelet,
in Hazar-shual, in Beersheba and its villages,
in Ziklag, in Meconah and its villages,
in En-rimmon, in Zorah, in Jarmuth,
in Zanoah, Adullam, and their villages, in Lachish and its fields, in Azekah and its villages. So they lived from Beersheba as far as the Valley of Hinnom.
verses.comment: The territory reaches as far as the Valley of Hinnom, which in later prophetic literature became associated with judgment (cf. Jer. 7:31-32).

verses.text: The sons of Benjamin also lived from Geba onward, at Michmash, Aija, Bethel and its villages,
Anathoth, Nob, Ananiah,
verses.comment: Anathoth was Jeremiah’s hometown, which links post-exilic settlement with prophetic tradition.

verses.text: Hazor, Ramah, Gittaim,
Hadid, Zeboim, Neballat,
Lod, and Ono, the Valley of Craftsmen.
And some of the divisions of the Levites of Judah were assigned to Benjamin.
verses.comment: Levites placed among the tribes signify the ongoing ministry of teaching and worship throughout the land, reinforcing unity and sacramental presence.
